Key Arguments: The Bill is seen as a censorial instrument that limits ideological and political narratives.
Digital platforms should not be held accountable for user-generated content, similar to how paper manufacturers are not responsible for printed words.
The Bill coerces digital platforms to censor content through threats of financial penalties and imprisonment.
Misinformation during the COVID-19 pandemic was often propagated by democratic institutions themselves.
The Bill will not restore trust in democratic institutions but will deepen mistrust.
The Bill does not adequately define 'truth' and does not consider the complexity and time required to ascertain it.
The ACMA should not be the arbiter of truth, as truth is distributed across multiple entities and not possessed by a single one.
The Bill could lead to totalitarian control over public discourse, akin to a dystopian society.
Notable Quotes: “… a nation that is afraid to let its people judge truth and falsehood in an open market is a nation that is afraid of its people.”
This Bill paves the way for totalitarian control over the modern-day Town Square.
The truth can only be determined through investigation, research, discussion and debate via the free-flowing, open exchange of ideas amongst lots of individuals – over time.
